Ken,

Thanks for your advice, sounds like I have a plan.

I think HMMs are =
on the "less restrictive" portion of the spectrum.  There
are some nuances =
that will have to be addressed (namely that probability
distributions have =
to sum to 1.0, and we need to decide how to interpret the
emissions), but I=
'm pretty confident that they can be dealt with sensibly
without having to =
get too fancy.

Daniel

On Sun, Dec 13, 2009 at 5:55 PM, Ken <kstanley@cs.u=
texas.edu> wrote:

>
>
>
>
> Daniel, sounds like an interesting project. NE=
AT is indeed a general method
> for evolving weighted connected graphs. How=
ever, it is also important to
> note that if you are trying to evolve a par=
ticular type of graph (i.e. with
> certain restrictions), it makes applying=
 NEAT to it more complicated. The
> less restricted the structure, the easi=
er it is to apply NEAT to it. For
> example, it is easy to evolve recurrent=
 networks with NEAT because it does
> not need to know if each connection i=
s recurrent or not. However, if you
> wanted to restrict recurrence, you wo=
uld have to keep track of information
> to allow you to detect whether a ne=
w link might be recurrent or not. If you
> were to evolve GP program trees,=
 the restrictions are even more severe, so
> that is even more tricky to se=
t up and guarantee coherence for all
> operations. I am not sure exactly wh=
ere HMMs lie on this continuum, but
> hopefully not too restricted (since t=
hen NEAT will be easier to set up for
> them).
>
> In terms of where to sta=
rt, I do think that my dissertation is a good
> reference for NEAT in gener=
al. It is true there are various bits that have
> been updated over time, l=
ike phased pruning, which could indeed be helpful.
> But these amendments c=
an be added later once the basic structure of the
> algorithm is validated.=
 Another potentially useful enhancement is Feature
> Selective NEAT (FS-NEA=
T), which allows you to start without all the inputs
> connected. Perhaps s=
omething like that could be useful for HMMs too. Here is
> a paper about FS=
-NEAT: http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?whiteson:gecco05
>
> Generally I thi=
nk the best approach is to start with the simplest possible
> version of NE=
AT (i.e. with the essentials of histortical marking,
> speciation, and comp=
lexification), validate that with XOR, and then continue
> from there to ma=
ke it more fancy if desired.
>
> ken
>
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com <nea=
t%40yahoogroups.com>, Daniel Tuohy
> <danielr2e@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hello,
=
> >
> > I'm planning this semester to investigate the applicability of the =
NEAT
> > algorithm to the evolution of Hidden Markov Models. I'm getting a =
PhD in
> > Bioinformatics, and HMMs have many applications to biological se=
quence
> > analysis. The HMMs used are currently built by hand and can be q=
uite
> > complex, and though there has been some successful research into e=
volving
> > them, none that I know of has attempted to take advantage of NE=
AT's bag
> o'
> > tricks.
> >
> > HMMs are very similar structurally to neu=
ral networks, and my suspicion
> is
> > that many of the same pathologies t=
hat confound the evolution neural
> > structures apply to HMMs. If I'm righ=
t, then NEAT seems like a very
> > attractive solution. I'm hoping that I c=
an use the NEAT algorithm almost
> in
> > it's entirety, since almost every=
thing seems applicable to this domain
> (and
> > I believe Ken has said tha=
t NEAT can be thought of as a general structure
> > evolving algorithm, rat=
her than being specific to ANNs).
> >
> > The first step is sorting out exa=
ctly what the canonical version of NEAT
> is.
> > My plan is to use Ken's d=
issertation as the primary reference. Is this
> > wise? Or have there been =
advances in the intervening years that I ought
> to
> > know about? For ins=
tance, one nuance that a colleague of mine at UT
> > mentioned is SharpNEAT=
's periodic decomplexification phase. He suspects
> > this phase is quite u=
seful, even though it is not part of the original
> NEAT
> > spec. What do =
you guys think?
> >
> > Ken, if you were to set one of your students to the=
 task of writing their
> > own NEAT from scratch, which resources would you=
 point him/her to?
> >
> > Daniel
> >
>
>  
>

Ken,<div><br></div><div>Thanks for your advice, sounds like I have a plan.<=
/div><div><br></div><div>I think HMMs are on the "less restrictive&quo=
t; portion of the spectrum. =A0There are some nuances that will have to be =
addressed (namely that probability distributions have to sum to 1.0, and we=
 need to decide how to interpret the emissions), but I'm pretty confide=
nt that they can be dealt with sensibly without having to get too fancy.<br=
>

<br></div><div>Daniel</div><div><br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Sun, D=
ec 13, 2009 at 5:55 PM, Ken <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:kstanle=
y@...">kstanley@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquot=
e class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc sol=
id;padding-left:1ex;">















<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">=

<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p><br>
<=
br>
Daniel, sounds like an interesting project.  NEAT is indeed a general m=
ethod for evolving weighted connected graphs.  However, it is also importan=
t to note that if you are trying to evolve a particular type of graph (i.e.=
 with certain restrictions), it makes applying NEAT to it more complicated.=
  The less restricted the structure, the easier it is to apply NEAT to it. =
 For example, it is easy to evolve recurrent networks with NEAT because it =
does not need to know if each connection is recurrent or not.  However, if =
you wanted to restrict recurrence, you would have to keep track of informat=
ion to allow you to detect whether a new link might be recurrent or not.  I=
f you were to evolve GP program trees, the restrictions are even more sever=
e, so that is even more tricky to set up and guarantee coherence for all op=
erations.  I am not sure exactly where HMMs lie on this continuum, but hope=
fully not too restricted (since then NEAT will be easier to set up for them=
).<br>


<br>
In terms of where to start, I do think that my dissertation i=
s a good reference for NEAT in general.  It is true there are various bits =
that have been updated over time, like phased pruning, which could indeed b=
e helpful.  But these amendments can be added later once the basic structur=
e of the algorithm is validated.  Another potentially useful enhancement is=
 Feature Selective NEAT (FS-NEAT), which allows you to start without all th=
e inputs connected.  Perhaps something like that could be useful for HMMs t=
oo.  Here is a paper about FS-NEAT: <a href=3D"http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyw=
ord?whiteson:gecco05" target=3D"_blank">http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/keyword?whi=
teson:gecco05</a><br>


<br>
Generally I think the best approach is to star=
t with the simplest possible version of NEAT (i.e. with the essentials of h=
istortical marking, speciation, and complexification), validate that with X=
OR, and then continue from there to make it more fancy if desired.<br>

<fo=
nt color=3D"#888888">
<br>
ken</font></p><div><div></div><div class=3D"h5">=
<br>

e solution.  I'm hoping that I can use the NEAT algorithm almost in<br>=

omain (and<br>
> I believe Ken has said that NEAT can be thought of as a=
 general structure<br>

to ANNs).<br>
> <br>
> The first step is sorting out exactly what the=
 canonical version of NEAT is.<br>
>  My plan is to use Ken's disser=
tation as the primary reference.  Is this<br>
> wise?  Or have there bee=
n advances in the intervening years that I ought to<br>
> know about?  F=
or instance, one nuance that a colleague of mine at UT<br>
> mentioned i=
s SharpNEAT's periodic decomplexification phase.  He suspects<br>
> =
this phase is quite useful, even though it is not part of the original NEAT=
<br>
> spec.  What do you guys think?<br>
> <br>
> Ken, if you wer=
e to set one of your students to the task of writing their<br>

T from scratch, which resources would you point him/her to?<br>
